{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3168562,"name":"Doruk Yıldırım","username":"Albiorin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/albiorin/{size}/213194_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T16:31:22.711Z","cooked":"

Hi all, we are currently in the middle of coding a Ramsete command for our robot. We have 4 NEO Brushless Motors on the drivetrain. The WPILib Docs say that we should get encoder distance values by using .getdistance() however for the NEO built-in encoders there is no such option. Are we making the import wrong? Or we should perhaps multiply the wheel diameter with some value we pull?

Here is how we’re currently instantiating our encoders:

private final RelativeEncoder m_leftEncoder = m_frontLeftSpark.getEncoder(); private final RelativeEncoder m_rightEncoder = m_frontRightSpark.getEncoder();

try getPosition()

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T16:36:20.117Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":46.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":430974,"topic_slug":"spark-max-encoder-missing-getdistance-function","display_username":"Paul Garrett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50008,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"7166/3655 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-encoder-missing-getdistance-function/430974/2","custom_user_title":"7166/3655 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3168566,"name":"","username":"Aqtion","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/2acd7d/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T16:37:43.577Z","cooked":"

I believe you’re looking for .getPosition(), which returns in units of rotations. You would use this output and convert it to the desired units with your wheel diameter, gearing, and basic geometry. You can utilize the .setPositionConversionFactor() to configure the encoder and scale its output to automatically provide the desired units.

That’s great! But how would I find out the scale factor I need?

The simple answer is math. It outputs in rotations, what are you looking to measure? Feet? Meters? Inches?

You wanna go from rotations of the motor to meters the robot travels.

setPositionConversionFactor(gearRatio * circumferenceOfWheelInMeters)
